_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Regal Fuels - Old Hickory Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws/codes.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Nashville Fire Department as well as the Nashville Office of Emergency Management, as necessary.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the Nashville Fire Department and TriStar Skyline Medical Center.  This facility has an Emergency Action Plan; however, does not maintain a trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team on-site to respond to the small initial stages of an emergency.



The Regal Fuels - Old Hickory Terminal is a butane transloading facility (specifically, railcar to truck tanker).  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the butane transloading system only, including the associated piping and five (5) storage tanks (detached railcars).



The Regal Fuels - Old Hickory Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) accident prevention rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119), the OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Standard (29 CFR 1910.120), and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  This butane transloading system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's (TRI-FLO Inc.) instructions.  Railcars meet the U.S. Department of Transportation Federal Railroad Administration design requirements for pressurized tank cars.



This is a new facility; therefore, it has never had an accident involving butane which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuation or shelterings in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Regal Fuels - Old Hickory Term

inal butane transloading system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Nashville Fire Department and request their assistance.  The facility personnel are trained.  The facility emergency action plans are coordinated with the fire departments and Nashville Office of Emergency Management.  The Nashville Fire Department is aware of the system and its available fire protection systems (site fire extinguishers and emergency shut-off devices).  The primary hazardous materials response capabilities are provided by the Nashville Fire Department.



Improvement actions to be considered primarily focus on site security and rail safety measures including continuing safety audits and safety inspections.
